Beyond Integers

Extension Theorem: Let D be a UFD or a Dedekind domain with unique factorization of ideals. Then φ extends to:

  • Rationals ℚ: Negative exponents encode denominators. For example, φ(1/3) = -φ(3), so φ(3/4) = [(2,-2),(3,1)].

  • Polynomials k[x]: Irreducible polynomials serve as primes; exponents represent factor multiplicity.

  • Algebraic Number Fields: In the ring of integers of a number field K, nonzero prime ideals act as primes, and φ maps each element to its ideal factor exponents.

  • Combinatorial domains: In set unions, singletons are primes; in graph unions, connected components are primes.

In each domain, φ assigns a finite exponent vector consistent with UOR's axioms. The coherence norm, spectral interpretation, and fiber bundle formalism remain valid, showcasing the uniform applicability of UOR across algebraic, combinatorial, and arithmetic landscapes.
